issues.text: Whether, under s. 5(1) of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949 as amended by the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Amendment Act, 1953, execution proceedings taken out by the decree-holder against the thika tenant could be entertained only by the Controller and not by the civil courts

anchor.surface_text: under s. 5  1  of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act, 1949  West Bengal II of 1949  as amended by the Calcutta Thika Tenancy  Amendment  Act, 1953  West Bengal VI of 1953 , execution proceedings taken out by the decrees against him companyld be entertained only by the companytroller and number by the civil companyrts.

issues.text: What is the proper construction of s. 5(1) of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act regarding the jurisdiction to entertain execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention is that the view taken by the courts below about the competence of the civil courts to entertain the decree-holders execution application proceeds on a misconstruction of s. 5 1 of the Calcutta Thika Tenancy Act. That is how the only question which arises for our decision is about the construction of the said relevant section.

issues.text: Whether s. 5(1) applies to a decree-holder seeking execution of an existing ejectment decree or only to a landlord initiating original proceedings to eject on grounds specified in s. 3

anchor.surface_text: Section 5, sub-s.  1  deals with cases where the landlord initiates original proceedings for ejecting his thika tenant. This sub-section refers to a landlord wishing to eject a thika tenant on one or more of the grounds specified in s. 3. Now this description is wholly inapplicable to a landlord who holds a decree for ejectment in his favour.

issues.text: Whether the deletion of the words 'but subject to the provisions of s. 28' from s. 5(1) and the omission of s. 28 by the 1953 Amendment Act enlarges the Controller's jurisdiction to include execution of pre-existing decrees

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Chatterjee, however, suggests that the deletion of the words subject to the provisions of s. 28 which originally occurred in s. 5 indicates that the Controller has been given jurisdiction not only to entertain original applications for ejectment made by the landlords but also to deal with decrees already passed in their favour.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants contention is that the effect of ss. 5, 28 and 29 was to submit the claims of landlords for ejectment of the thika tenants to a scrutiny in the light of the provisions of s. 3 and other relevant sections of the Act. anchor.surface_text: Section 5, sub-s.  1  deals with cases where the landlord initiates original proceedings for ejecting his thika tenant.
